title: 114_hr2791
content: The "Western Oregon Tribal Fairness Act" includes provisions for land conveyance for Cow Creek Umpqua, Coquille Forest, and Oregon Coastal Lands. The Act consists of three titles outlining the conveyance, definitions, administration, and land reclassification for each tribal area. The "Cow Creek Umpqua Land Conveyance Act" defines terms like Council Creek land, Tribe, and Secretary. It involves the conveyance of approximately 17,519 acres of land to the Cow Creek Band of Umpqua Tribe of Indians. SEC. 103 of the "Cow Creek Umpqua Land Conveyance Act" conveys the Council Creek land to the Tribe, held in trust by the United States. A survey to establish boundaries must be completed within a year. SEC. 104 requires the Secretary to file a map and legal description of the Council Creek land with specified committees. The filed map and legal description will have the same force and effect as if included in the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct errors. The information will be available for public inspection. SEC. 105. ADMINISTRATION. This section clarifies that existing tribal rights to land are unaffected by the Act unless specified. It prohibits the export of unprocessed logs from Council Creek land and restricts gaming activities on land taken into trust. Forest management on the land must comply with Federal laws. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary must identify Oregon and California Railroad grant land held in trust for the Tribe. Public domain land in Oregon must also be identified, similar in acreage and condition to the grant land. Maps must be submitted to Congress and published within 2 years of the Act's enactment. After identifying the Oregon and California Railroad grant land held in trust for the Tribe, the Secretary shall reclassify the land as Oregon and California Railroad grant land after public comment. The Act of August 28, 1937, shall apply to the reclassified land. The "Coquille Forest Fairness Act" is a title that includes amendments to the Coquille Restoration Act. Section 5(d) of the Coquille Restoration Act is amended to specify the management of the Coquille Forest, including restrictions on the export of unprocessed logs. Federal land sales of timber subject to competitive bidding practices, with highest responsible bidder awarded. Strike paragraph (9) and redesignate paragraphs (10) through (12). The "Oregon Coastal Lands Act" defines terms like Confederated Tribes and Oregon Coastal land, encompassing approximately 14,408 acres. The Secretary of the Interior is involved in the conveyance process. SEC. 303 of the "Oregon Coastal Lands Act" conveys all right, title, and interest of the United States in the Oregon Coastal land to the Confederated Tribes. The land will be held in trust for the tribes, and a survey of the boundary lines must be completed within a year. SEC. 304 of the "Oregon Coastal Lands Act" requires the Secretary to file a map and legal description of the Oregon Coastal land with specified committees. The filed map and legal description will have the same force and effect as if included in the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct any errors. The information will be available for public inspection. (a) Unless provided otherwise in this title, existing rights of Confederated Tribes to land are preserved. (b) Prohibitions include restrictions on exporting unprocessed logs from Oregon Coastal land and prohibiting gaming activities on land taken into trust. (c) Commercial forestry activities on Oregon Coastal land are subject to applicable laws. Commercial forestry activities on Oregon Coastal land taken into trust under section 303 must comply with all relevant Federal laws. The Confederated Tribes will work with the Secretary to develop agreements for access to the land, including honoring existing agreements, providing administrative access to the Bureau of Land Management, and managing acquired or developed lands in accordance with the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act. Land use planning requirements apply unless specified otherwise. Once Oregon Coastal land is taken into trust under section 303, it is not subject to the land use planning requirements of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 or the Act of August 28, 1937. SEC. 306. LAND RECLASSIFICATION. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary must identify Oregon and California Railroad grant land held in trust for the Confederated Tribes within 180 days. Within 18 months, public domain land in Oregon similar in acreage and condition must be identified. Maps must be submitted to Congress and published within 2 years of the enactment of this Act. After identifying the Oregon and California Railroad grant land held in trust for the Confederated Tribes, the Secretary must reclassify the land following a public comment period. The House of Representatives passed a bill to reclassify Oregon and California Railroad grant land, with the Act of August 28, 1937 applying to the reclassified land.
